semantic_title: Default Coding for Diabetes Mellitus Type Not Documented
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 4. Chapter 4: Endocrine, Nutritional, and Metabolic Diseases > a. Diabetes mellitus > 2) Type of diabetes mellitus not documented

content.full_text: If the type of diabetes mellitus is not documented in the medical record the default is E11.-, Type 2 diabetes mellitus. (Evidence: pg no: 40, L36-L37)
content.summary: Default coding rule for diabetes when type is not specified in documentation - use Type 2 diabetes codes (Evidence: pg no: 40, L36-L37)
key_concepts: Default to Type 2 diabetes when type not documented (Evidence: pg no: 40, L37)
Use E11.- code range for unspecified diabetes type (Evidence: pg no: 40, L37)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Default to E11.- when diabetes type not documented (Evidence: pg no: 40, L37)
detailed_rules.explanation: When the medical record documents diabetes mellitus but does not specify the type, assign a code from category E11, Type 2 diabetes mellitus (Evidence: pg no: 40, L36-L37)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Review documentation for diabetes diagnosis
Step 2: Look for specification of diabetes type
Step 3: If type not documented, default to Type 2
Step 4: Assign appropriate E11.- code based on complications

code_ranges.description: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (Evidence: pg no: 40, L37)
code_ranges.requirement: Default when diabetes type not specified
usage_rules: Use when diabetes type not documented (Evidence: pg no: 40, L36-L37)
Select specific code based on complications present

coding_scenarios.scenario: Diabetes mellitus documented without type specification
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient has diabetes mellitus with diabetic nephropathy
step_by_step: Step 2: Note no type specification in documentation
Step 3: Apply default rule for Type 2 diabetes
Step 4: Assign E11.21 for Type 2 with nephropathy

correct_coding.rationale: Default to Type 2 when type not specified (Evidence: pg no: 40, L36-L37)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Should not assume Type 1 diabetes without documentation
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Guessing diabetes type instead of using default

breakdown.E11: Type 2 diabetes mellitus (default) (Evidence: pg no: 40, L37)

examples.rationale: Default to Type 2 when diabetes type not documented (Evidence: pg no: 40, L36-L37)

warnings: Do not guess diabetes type - use default Type 2 (Evidence: pg no: 40, L36-L37)
best_practices: Always check documentation for diabetes type specification (Evidence: pg no: 40, L36-L37)
Use E11.- codes as default for unspecified type (Evidence: pg no: 40, L37)
tips: Type 2 diabetes is the default for unspecified cases (Evidence: pg no: 40, L37)
implementation_notes: Applies when documentation lacks type specification
Still need to identify complications present
clinical_context: Type 2 diabetes is more common than Type 1
